3396 def calcReNorm1(self, R, checkFit=False, doplot=False, iden='', verbose=True): 

3397 """ 

3398 Purpose: 

3399 Perform a simple polynomial fit to the renormalization scaling  

3400 spectrum to remove any residual baseline ripples. Used within the 

3401 renormalize method to fit a baseline to each segment of the full  

3402 spectrum.  

3403 

3404 Note that this operates directly on the input spectrum! 

3405 

3406 Inputs: 

3407 R : numpy.array 

3408 Scaling spectrum for a specific scan, spw, field and pol. 

3409 

3410 doplot : boolean : OPTIONAL 

3411 If set to True, produce a plot showing the polynomial fits  

3412 that have been applied to the data.  

3413 

3414 iden : str : OPTIONAL 

3415 An optional identifier to append to image names to make them 

3416 unique, otherwise they will get written over.  

3417 

3418 Outputs: 

3419 None directly, but note that the input scaling spectrum will be  

3420 adjusted directly. 

3421 

3422 Notes for Improvement: 

3423 In some cases, there are segments where an ATM feature is near the 

3424 edge of the segment and leaves just a few channels of data. Thus, 

3425 there are a few valid channels, then a gap, then the rest of the  

3426 segment data. The few channels of data will sometimes end up  

3427 just outside the threshold and then end up skewed wildly and can 

3428 result in false application. One could force the fit to always 

3429 include data from both sides of an ATM feature but what if it's 

3430 a real feature? Force a wider segment? 

3431 """ 

3432 # NB: R will be adjust in place 

3433 

3434 nCha=len(R) 

3435 

3436 x=np.array(range(nCha))*1.0/nCha - 0.5 

3437 

3438 mask=np.ones(len(R),bool) 

3439 ylim=0.0 

3440 

3441 if doplot: 

3442 plt.ioff() 

3443 plt.clf() 

3444 fig = plt.figure(figsize=(20,10)) 

3445 

3446 # Find where ATM was masked 

3447 atm_masked = np.where(R==1.0)[0] 

3448 

3449 atm_mask = mask 

3450 atm_mask[atm_masked] = False 

3451 

3452 # initial "fit" - Ignoring atm regions 

3453 if len(R[atm_mask]) == 0: 

3454 casalog.post(' WARN: No data left in segment after removing atm features.') 

3455 refit=True 

3456 return refit 

3457 else: 

3458 f=np.array([np.median(R[atm_mask])]) 

3459 

3460 

3461 for ifit in range(1,self.nfit): 

3462 

3463 R0=R.copy() 

3464 

3465 # ~flattened, zeroed spectrum 

3466 R0/=np.polyval(f,x) 

3467 R0-=1.0 

3468 

3469 # thresh is half peak negative 

3470 #thresh=abs(R0.min()/2.0) 

3471 

3472 # thresh is 2x median deviation (~1.33 sigma)  

3473 # need to ignore regions of the spectrum with atm features 

3474 thresh=np.median(np.absolute(R0[atm_mask]))*2.0 

3475 

3476 # mask outside thresh 

3477 mask[:]=True 

3478 mask[R0<-thresh]=False 

3479 mask[R0>thresh]=False 

3480 

3481 # This was meant to check for line forest like data but ultimately 

3482 # just fails when there is an atm feature and noisy data 

3483 #if checkFit: 

3484 # if sum(mask)/len(mask) > 0.5: 

3485 # refit=False 

3486 # else: 

3487 # if verbose: 

3488 # casalog.post(' WARN: More than 50% of the selected data is masked in the fit.') 

3489 # refit=True 

3490 # # Exit here since we need to refit anyway, no sense in 

3491 # # wasting compute time. There's also a small chance that 

3492 # # the entire segment is masked from an atm feature. 

3493 # return refit 

3494 

3495 # ignore ATM masked regions 

3496 mask[atm_masked]=False 

3497 

3498 if checkFit: 

3499 if sum(mask)/len(mask) > 0.1: 

3500 refit=False 

3501 else: 

3502 if verbose: 

3503 casalog.post(' WARN: Less than 10% of the selected data is available ' \ 

3504 +'to fit likely due to atm and/or science line features.') 

3505 refit=True 

3506 # Exit here since we need to refit because there's  

3507 # almost no data left. 

3508 return refit 

3509 

3510 if doplot: 

3511 med=np.median(R) 

3512 plt.subplot(2,self.nfit,ifit) 

3513 plt.plot(range(nCha),R,'b,', label='Data') 

3514 plt.plot( 

3515 np.array(range(nCha))[np.logical_not(mask)], 

3516 R[np.logical_not(mask)], 

3517 'r.', 

3518 label='Masked' 

3519 ) 

3520 plt.plot(range(nCha),np.polyval(f,x),'r-', label='Initial/Last Fit') 

3521 #plt.axis([-1,nCha,med-0.003,med+0.003]) 

3522 

3523 if ylim==0.0: 

3524 ylim=5*thresh 

3525 plt.subplot(2,self.nfit,ifit+self.nfit) 

3526 plt.plot(range(nCha),R0,'b,', label='Data after last fit') 

3527 plt.plot([-1,nCha],[-thresh,-thresh],'r:', label='Threshold') 

3528 plt.plot([-1,nCha],[thresh,thresh],'r:') 

3529 #plt.axis([-1,nCha,-ylim,ylim]) 

3530 #casalog.post(ifit-1, thresh, abs(R0.min()/2.0), np.sum(mask), f) 

3531 plt.legend() 

3532 

3533 # fit to _R_ in masked spectra 

3534 f=np.polyfit(x[mask],R[mask],ifit) 

3535 

3536 if doplot: 

3537 plt.subplot(2,self.nfit,ifit) 

3538 plt.plot(range(nCha),np.polyval(f,x),'g-', label='N='+str(ifit)+' Fit') 

3539 #casalog.post(ifit, f) 

3540 plt.legend() 

3541 

3542 R/=np.polyval(f,x) 

3543 

3544 # reset ATM masked region 

3545 R[atm_masked] = 1.0 

3546 

3547 if doplot: 

3548 os.makedirs('RN_plots', exist_ok=True) 

3549 plt.subplot(2,self.nfit,ifit+1) 

3550 plt.plot(range(nCha),R,'g-') 

3551 plt.title('Final Data After Fitting') 

3552 plt.savefig( 

3553 './RN_plots/seg_fitting_results_'+iden+'.png', 

3554 format='png', 

3555 bbox_inches='tight' 

3556 ) 

3557 plt.close() 

3558 

3559 if checkFit: 

3560 return refit 

3561 

3562 def calcRenormLegendre(self, R, nseg): 

3563 """ 

3564 Purpose: 

3565 Perform a fit to the renormalization spectrum to flatten the  

3566 profile and make it so that outside of spectral features the  

3567 data is unchanged (i.e. multiplied by 1.0). Here, Legendre  

3568 polynomials are used for the fitting process.  

3569 

3570 Inputs: 

3571 R : numpy.array 

3572 This is the segment of renormalization spectrum you wish to  

3573 perform a fit on.  

3574 

3575 nseg : integer 

3576 This is the number of segments that calcChannelRanges()  

3577 suggested. This function will decide on the order of the fit  

3578 based on the number of segments and the self.nfit parameter  

3579 as self.nfit*nseg. 

3580 """ 

3581 # First we make a quick copy of the array. We are going to need to  

3582 # ignore sections of the spectrum where actual spectral features exist  

3583 # so we quickly operate on a copy but perform the fit on the actual  

3584 # given array. 

3585 R0 = R.copy() 

3586 

3587 # Define x 

3588 x = np.linspace(0,len(R0)-1, len(R0)) 

3589 

3590 # Legendre polynomials are bounded within [-1,1] so convert our x to  

3591 # that space. 

3592 nx = 2*x/x[-1] - 1 

3593 

3594 # An "initial fit" to our array copy just to somewhat flatten it and  

3595 # move everything to around 0.0. 

3596 ifit = np.array([np.median(R0)]) 

3597 R0 = R0/np.polyval(ifit,x) - 1.0 

3598 

3599 # Now find where there are spectral features and create a mask on them. 

3600 thresh = np.median(np.absolute(R0)) * 3.0 

3601 mask = np.ones(len(R), bool) 

3602 mask[:] = True 

3603 mask[R0 <- thresh] = False 

3604 mask[R0 > thresh] = False 

3605 

3606 # Perform the least-squares fit to everywhere else in the real  

3607 # given array 

3608 coeffs = np.polynomial.legendre.legfit( 

3609 nx[mask], 

3610 R[mask], 

3611 self.nfit*nseg 

3612 ) 

3613 

3614 # Evaluate the amplitudes from out fit. 

3615 fit = np.polynomial.legendre.legval( 

3616 nx, 

3617 coeffs 

3618 ) 

3619 

3620 # Apply the fit to our data. 

3621 R = R/fit 

3622 return R 

3623 

3624 

3625 def checkOutlierAnt(self, R): 

3626 """ 

3627 Purpose: 

3628 Perform a check of each antenna in a renormalization spectrum 

3629 dictionary and return a list of possibly problematic antenna 

3630 that may need flagging due to outlier data (e.g. from birdies). 

3631 

3632 Inputs: 

3633 R : dictionary 

3634 The renormalization spectrum as created by the renormalize() 

3635 method. 

3636 

3637 Outputs: 

3638 AntChk : list of strings 

3639 A list of antennas that may contain problematic data which  

3640 can be used as input for the calcFixReNorm method. 

3641 """ 

3642 AntChk=[] 

3643 

3644 # Median spectra for each pol. In principle all ants should be the  

3645 # same per field. Need to be careful to avoid an issue if there are  

3646 # too many 1.0's from flagged data - median ends up being 1.0!  

3647 # Exclude channels that equal 1.0 for taking the median and then  

3648 # replace them after the calculation so we don't have to deal with NaN. 

3649 M = np.nanmedian(np.where(R!=1,R,np.nan),2) 

3650 M[:][np.isnan(M[:])]=1.0 

3651 

3652 # Median in channel axis. Left with MAD per corr per ant,  

3653 # then median of all 

3654 medMAD =np.median(np.median(np.absolute(R - 1.0),1)) 

3655 

3656 # Mean max value per pol - as above 

3657 Rmax=np.mean(R.max(1),1) 

3658 

3659 # Values <0.25% are trivial 

3660 thresh = 1.0025 

3661 

3662 # TBD some bad ants have >1.025 

3663 for jcor in range(R.shape[0]): 

3664 # set thresh to avoid a line free spectrum defining  

3665 # 'noise' as differences 

3666 RmaxT = np.maximum(Rmax[jcor]-1.0,0.0025) 

3667 

3668 # first review the median for birdies (same as the calcFixReNorm), 

3669 # pass over a range and check for huge spikes 

3670 for nch in range(10,M.shape[1]-10): 

3671 if np.absolute(np.median(M[jcor,nch-2:nch+3])-M[jcor,nch]) > 0.5*RmaxT: 

3672 M[jcor,nch]=np.median(M[jcor,nch-2:nch+3]) 

3673 

3674 for jant in range(R.shape[2]): 

3675 Rcomp = 1.0+np.absolute((R[jcor,:,jant]/M[jcor,:])-1.0) 

3676 

3677 # now check if any channel triggers a real outlier - do not assess  

3678 # per channel here just store to the outlier ant list for detailed  

3679 # investigation later 

3680 if Rcomp.max(0) > thresh and jant not in AntChk: 

3681 AntChk.append(jant) 

3682 

3683 return AntChk 

3684 

3685 def calcFixReNorm( 

3686 self, 

3687 R, 

3688 AntUse, 

3689 scanin, 

3690 spwin, 

3691 fldin, 

3692 doplot=True, 

3693 plotDivisions=True, 

3694 hardcopy=True, 

3695 verbose=False 

3696 ): 

3697 """ 

3698 Purpose: 

3699 This function takes in a renormalization spectrum and performs a  

3700 set of heuristics to check for outliers caused by issues with the 

3701 autocorrelations (e.g. birdies). Outlier channels are replaced with 

3702 the median spectrum. If many channels are found to be outliers  

3703 (greater than 10 consecutive channels or >10% of total spectrum),  

3704 then the whole median spectrum of that correlation is used for the  

3705 replacement instead.  

3706 

3707 Note that this operates on the input renormalization spectrum  

3708 directly! Therefore the input spectrum will be directly adjusted. 

3709 

3710 Inputs: 

3711 R : dictionary 

3712 The renormalization spectrum as created by the renormalize() 

3713 method. 

3714 

3715 AntUse : list of strings 

3716 This is a list of antennas to investigate for outliers. The 

3717 checkOutlierAnt method will return an appropriate list to 

3718 be used as input here. 

3719 

3720 scanin : string 

3721 The scan number to check. 

3722 

3723 spwin : string 

3724 The spw number to check. 

3725 

3726 fldin : string 

3727 The field number to check. 

3728 

3729 doplot : boolean : OPTIONAL 

3730 If set to True, produce plots that show original spectrum 

3731 and replaced values.  

3732 Default: True 

3733 

3734 plotDivisions : boolean : OPTIONAL 

3735 If set to True, then include vertical lines of the plots that 

3736 show where the spectrum was divided up during the fitting  

3737 process of the calcReNorm1 method. 

3738 Default: True 

3739 

3740 hardcopy : boolean : OPTIONAL 

3741 If set to True, save a hardcopy of the produced plot to disk. 

3742 Default: True 

3743 

3744 verbose : boolean : OPTIONAL 

3745 If set to True, produce additional output. 

3746 Default: False 

3747 

3748 Outputs: 

3749 The input renormalization spectrum, R, is operated on directly. 

3750 No additional output is generated. 

3751 

3752 Notes for Improvement:  

3753 If AntUse is not defined, could default to running checkOutlierAnt 

3754 method by default. 

3755 """ 

3756 # Median spectra for each pol - in principle all ants should be the  

3757 # same per field. However, there can be a problem if there are too  

3758 # many 1.0's from flagged data because median ends up being 1.0. For 

3759 # excluded chan ranges which are 'nan' need to set back to 1.0,  

3760 # otherwise median has nan values and rest of stats max, min, etc  

3761 # do not deal with it. 

3762 M = np.nanmedian(np.where(R!=1,R,np.nan),2) 

3763 M[:][np.isnan(M[:])]=1.0 

3764 Mabs = 1.0+np.absolute(M-1.0) 

3765 

3766 # mean max value per pol - as above 

3767 Rmax = np.mean(R.max(1),1) 

3768 Rmin = np.mean(R.min(1),1) 

3769 

3770 # Median in channel axis. Left with MAD per corr per ant,  

3771 # then median of all 

3772 medMAD = np.median(np.median(np.absolute(R - 1.0),1)) 

3773 

3774 # Scales of this magnitude are negligable  

3775 thresh = 1.0025 

3776 

3777 if doplot: 

3778 # Make a copy for plotting 

3779 Rorig = R.copy() 

3780 

3781 # Assuming 2 corr/pols but this doesn't hurt single pol or full pol 

3782 lineOut=[[],[]] 

3783 plttxt=[[],[]] 

3784 corPrt=['XX','YY'] 

3785 

3786 # This repeats the median spectrum making and checking actively - fast  

3787 # so just copied as from cehckOutlierAnt code  

3788 for jcor in range(R.shape[0]): 

3789 

3790 RmaxT = np.maximum(Rmax[jcor]-1.0,0.0025) 

3791 

3792 for nch in range(10,M.shape[1]-10): 

3793 if np.absolute(np.median(M[jcor,nch-2:nch+3])-M[jcor,nch]) > 0.5*RmaxT: 

3794 M[jcor,nch]=np.median(M[jcor,nch-2:nch+3]) 

3795 self.birdiechan[str(spwin)].append( 

3796 'chan'+str(nch)+'_scan'+str(scanin)+'_field'+str(fldin) 

3797 ) 

3798 

3799 # setup threshold, for the read in spw, scan, field 

3800 thresharr=M.copy() 

3801 

3802 # Now we set to a max value of either thresh or the median array max taken over 10  

3803 # channels assesses +/- 5 chans max values in median spec and then compares with  

3804 # thresh and attributes to the max over +/- 5 assessed over the same 5 channels if  

3805 # over thresh acts as the buffer the not miss -ve in absorbtion features (black- 

3806 # dashed in plot) set to +/- 10 now due to abs/emm CO lines in ALMA-IMF data  

3807 for jcor in range(R.shape[0]): 

3808 thresharr[jcor,0:10][thresharr[jcor,0:10]<thresh]=thresh # set ends 

3809 thresharr[jcor,-10:][thresharr[jcor,-10:]<thresh]=thresh # set ends 

3810 thresharr[jcor,10:-10]=[ 

3811 thresh 

3812 if thresharr[jcor,nch-10:nch+10].max(0) < thresh 

3813 else thresharr[jcor,nch-10:nch+10].max(0) 

3814 for nch in range(10,M.shape[1]-10) 

3815 ] 

3816 

3817 

3818 # loops ants that triggered in outlier list 

3819 for jant in AntUse: 

3820 

3821 # append to known dict if not there already 

3822 if self.AntName[jant] not in self.AntOut[str(spwin)].keys(): 

3823 self.AntOut[str(spwin)][self.AntName[jant]]={} 

3824 

3825 # for later logic of action if required 

3826 replaceCorr = [False for iCor in range(self.num_corrs)] 

3827 

3828 for jcor in range(R.shape[0]): 

3829 

3830 Rcomp = 1.0+np.absolute((R[jcor,:,jant]/M[jcor,:])-1.0) 

3831 # make channel based assessment and reset to specific channel value in median  

3832 # spectrum (default operation) but as we replace we store how many channels  

3833 # are replaced for later logic 

3834 R[jcor,:,jant] = [ 

3835 M[jcor][nch] 

3836 if Rcomp[nch]>thresharr[jcor][nch] 

3837 else R[jcor,:,jant][nch] 

3838 for nch in range(M.shape[1]) 

3839 ] 

3840 lineOut[jcor]=[ 

3841 spl 

3842 for spl in range(M.shape[1]) 

3843 if Rcomp[spl]>thresharr[jcor][spl] 

3844 ] 

3845 

3846 # store a print statement for plot - can be later overwritten 

3847 plttxt[jcor]=' **** Replace flagged channels with that from median spectrum **** ' 

3848 if len(lineOut[jcor])>0: 

3849 if verbose: 

3850 casalog.post('\tOutlier antenna identified '+str(self.AntName[jant]) \ 

3851 +' '+str(corPrt[jcor])+' will repair outlier channels') 

3852 

3853 # open the list for outlier channels if not already existing (fill below) 

3854 if corPrt[jcor] not in self.AntOut[str(spwin)][self.AntName[jant]].keys(): 

3855 self.AntOut[str(spwin)][self.AntName[jant]][corPrt[jcor]]=[] 

3856 

3857 # also want to know the maximum consecutive channels  

3858 maxConseq = self.calcMaxConseq(lineOut[jcor]) 

3859 

3860 # if there are more than 10 consecutive lines replace with median spectrum 

3861 if maxConseq > 10: 

3862 replaceCorr[jcor]=True 

3863 else: 

3864 # There were no triggered lines, maybe only one pol was  

3865 # bad - don't assess any further. It triggered the  

3866 # outlierAnt but this pol wasn't bad 

3867 continue 

3868 

3869 # If we find a lot of outlier channels, or the consecutive  

3870 # amount of bad channels is triggered, we work out what action  

3871 # to take - 10% of SPW must be bad in total - this is a hard  

3872 # coded choice  

3873 if len(lineOut[jcor])>0.1*M.shape[1] or replaceCorr[jcor]: 

3874 R[jcor,:,jant]=M[jcor] 

3875 plttxt[jcor]=' **** Replaced '+corPrt[jcor]+' spectrum with median ' \ 

3876 +corPrt[jcor]+' spectrum **** ' 

3877 

3878 # Only plot those where some replacement of the spectrum was needed 

3879 if len(lineOut[jcor]) < 10 \ 

3880 and set( 

3881 lineOut[jcor] 

3882 ).issubset( 

3883 self.AntOut[str(spwin)][self.AntName[jant]][corPrt[jcor]] 

3884 ): 

3885 # usually plot the per spw, per scan, per field correction made, but if that  

3886 # ant was shown already, don't repeat i.e. known as problematic don't really  

3887 # need to show the same channel 'fix' for all scans/fields 

3888 if hardcopy and doplot: 

3889 if verbose: 

3890 casalog.post('\tNot saving hardcopy - ' \ 

3891 + 'channels already identified for this antenna') 

3892 continue 

3893 elif maxConseq < 10: 

3894 if hardcopy and doplot: 

3895 if verbose: 

3896 casalog.post('\tNot saving hardcopy - ' \ 

3897 +'less than 10 conseq channels adjusted - ' \ 

3898 +'only birdies outliers') 

3899 continue 

3900 else: 

3901 # extend the list to add known channels now and follow to the plots 

3902 self.AntOut[str(spwin)][self.AntName[jant]][corPrt[jcor]].extend( 

3903 [ 

3904 lineO 

3905 for lineO in lineOut[jcor] 

3906 if lineO not in \ 

3907 self.AntOut[str(spwin)][self.AntName[jant]][corPrt[jcor]] 

3908 ] 

3909 ) 

3910 

3911 # These are the heuristics diagnostic plots to be used for  

3912 # checking the heuristics logic to see what was occuring. This 

3913 # can make 100+ plots, so if heursitics are trusted they don't  

3914 # really need investigation and are mostly for testing and  

3915 # deep dives later if needed. 

3916 if doplot: 

3917 # Initialize figure and clear buffer 

3918 plt.ioff() 

3919 plt.clf() 

3920 fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10,8)) 

3921 ax = fig.add_subplot(111,frame_on=False) 

3922 

3923 # Plot the original renorm spectrum, the comparison median spectrum,  

3924 # the adjusted spectra, and the threshold. 

3925 ax.plot(Rorig[jcor,:,jant],c='r',linestyle='--', label='Orig. Spec.') 

3926 ax.plot(Rcomp,c='b',label='Divided (comp) spec.',alpha=0.5) 

3927 ax.plot(M[jcor],c='g',linewidth='2', label='Median Spec.') 

3928 ax.plot(R[jcor,:,jant],c='k',label='New Spec.') 

3929 ax.plot( 

3930 thresharr[jcor], 

3931 c='0.5', 

3932 alpha=0.5, 

3933 linestyle='--', 

3934 linewidth='3', 

3935 label='Threshold' 

3936 ) 

3937 

3938 # Plot any birdies/outliers that have been found 

3939 for lineP in lineOut[jcor]: 

3940 ax.plot(lineP,0.999,c='y',marker='s') 

3941 # to get the single label 

3942 ax.plot(lineOut[jcor][0],0.999,c='y',marker='s', label='Outlier Chns.') 

3943 

3944 # Find the data edges to set plot size 

3945 pltmin=np.array( 

3946 [R[jcor,:,jant].min(0),0.9977,Rorig[jcor,:,jant].min(0)] 

3947 ).min(0) 

3948 Pmax = np.array( 

3949 [R[jcor,:,jant].max(0),1.015,Rcomp.max(0),thresharr[jcor].max(0)] 

3950 ).max(0) 

3951 pltmax= 1.+(Pmax-1.)*1.10 

3952 ax.axis([0.0,M.shape[1],pltmin,pltmax]) 

3953 

3954 # If a substitution was made above, inform on plot 

3955 if plttxt[jcor]: 

3956 ax.text(0,1.+(Pmax-1.)*1.04,plttxt[jcor]) 

3957 

3958 # If selected, plot the locations where the spectrum was broken up  

3959 # during fitting 

3960 if plotDivisions: 

3961 target = self.msmeta.namesforfields(fldin)[0] 

3962 dNchan = self.rnstats['inputs'][target][str(spwin)]['dNchan'][-1] 

3963 nseg = self.rnstats['inputs'][target][str(spwin)]['num_segments'][-1] 

3964 # if there is only 1 segment, then no lines to draw 

3965 if nseg==1: 

3966 plotDivisions=False 

3967 else: 

3968 xlocs = [iseg*dNchan for iseg in range(1,nseg)] 

3969 ax.vlines( 

3970 xlocs, 

3971 0.5, 

3972 5, 

3973 linestyles='dotted', 

3974 colors='grey', 

3975 alpha=0.5, 

3976 zorder=10 

3977 ) 

3978 ax.set_xlabel('Channels') 

3979 ax.set_ylabel('ReNorm Scaling') 

3980 fname=self.msname+'_ReNormHeuristicOutlierAnt_' + self.AntName[jant] \ 

3981 + '_spw' + str(spwin) \ 

3982 + '_scan' + str(scanin) \ 

3983 + '_field' + str(fldin) \ 

3984 + '_'+corPrt[jcor] 

3985 ax.set_title( 

3986 self.msname 

3987 + '\nAntenna ' + self.AntName[jant] 

3988 + ' Spw: ' + str(spwin) 

3989 + ' Scan: ' + str(scanin) 

3990 + ' Field: ' + str(fldin) 

3991 + ' Corr: ' + corPrt[jcor], 

3992 {'fontsize': 'medium'} 

3993 ) 

3994 

3995 # legend lines 

3996 ax.legend( 

3997 loc='lower center', 

3998 bbox_to_anchor=(0.5,-0.28), 

3999 prop={'size':8}, 

4000 ncol=3 

4001 ) 

4002 fig.subplots_adjust(bottom=0.20) 

4003 

4004 # Create secondary x-axis with frequency labels 

4005 freqs = self.msmeta.chanfreqs(spwin,'GHz') 

4006 ax1 = ax.twiny() 

4007 ax1.set_xlabel('Frequency (GHz) (TOPO)') 

4008 ax1.set_xlim(freqs[0],freqs[-1]) 

4009 ax1.ticklabel_format(useOffset=False) 

4010 

4011 # Save a hardcopy of the plots if desired  

4012 # or show plots interactively 

4013 if hardcopy: 

4014 os.makedirs('RN_plots', exist_ok=True) 

4015 if verbose: 

4016 casalog.post('\tSaving hardcopy plot: '+fname) 

4017 plt.savefig('./RN_plots/'+fname+'.png') 

4018 plt.close('all') 

4019 else: 

4020 plt.show() 

4021 

4022 

4023 

4024 # Main diagnostic spectra at lowest level - scaling that each spw, scan, field, ant, correlation will have 

4025 # these plots should look good 

4026 def plotdiagSpectra( 

4027 self, 

4028 R, 

4029 scanin, 

4030 spwin, 

4031 fldin, 

4032 threshline=None, 

4033 plotATM=True, 

4034 plotDivisions=True, 

4035 N_atm=None, 

4036 shadeAtm=True, 

4037 showExcluded=True 

4038 ): 

4039 """ 

4040 Purpose:  

4041 This creates diagnotic spectra at the per field per spectral window level for each scan. 

4042 Each antenna and correlation are plotted for each field. 

4043 Inputs: 

4044 R : numpy.array 

4045 This is the renormalization spectrum that you wish to plot. Requires data in the form 

4046 of a numpy array in the shape [correlation, channel, antenna] such that [0,:,0] would 

4047 be the 0-th correlation (XX), all channels, for the 0-th antenna (e.g. DA45) and would 

4048 be the found renormalization spectrum. 

4049 

4050 scanin : int 

4051 This is the scan number which corresponds to the renormalization spectrum supplied. 

4052 

4053 spwin : int 

4054 This is the spectral window number which corresponds to the renormalization spectrum 

4055 supplied. 

4056 

4057 fldin : int 

4058 This is the field number which corresponds to the normalization spectrum supplied. 

4059 

4060 plotATM : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4061 This option will plot (or not) the atmospheric transmission profile for the input 

4062 spectrum. 

4063 Default: True 

4064 

4065 plotDivisions : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4066 This option will plot (or not) the division lines as vertical, grey, dotted lines 

4067 at all the locations where the renormalization spectrum was broken up during the 

4068 fitting stage. 

4069 Default: True 

4070 

4071 threshLine : float or None : OPTIONAL 

4072 This option allows the user to draw a line of the plot to represent the threshold 

4073 level. 

4074 Default: None 

4075 

4076 N_atm : numpy.array OR None : OPTIONAL 

4077 Similar to R above, this is the renormalization spectrum that you want to plot except 

4078 this should be the renormalization spectrum that has not had any atmospheric corrections 

4079 applited to it. If provided, then this "original" data will be plotted showing the  

4080 differences between this and the renormalization spectrum that will be applied. 

4081 Default: None 

4082 

4083 shadeAtm : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4084 If set to True, this will find atmospheric features, fit them with a Lorentzian  

4085 profile and shade the regions of the spectrum influenced by the feature. 

4086 Default: True 

4087 

4088 showExcluded : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4089 If set to True, then areas of the spectrum that have been excluded via the  

4090 excludechan option in renormalize() will be shown.  

4091 Default: True 

4092  

4093 """ 

4094 

4095 # If an original Renormalization spectrum was provided (i.e. one without any atmospheric 

4096 # corrections applied to it) then find the median (avoiding zeros) so that we can overplot  

4097 # it to see the improvements directly. 

4098 if N_atm is not None: 

4099 plot_original = True 

4100 M_atm = np.nanmedian(np.where(N_atm!=1,N_atm,np.nan),2) 

4101 M_atm[:][np.isnan(M_atm[:])]=1.0 

4102 else: 

4103 plot_original = False 

4104 

4105 # Grab the median renormalization spectrum, avoiding values set to exactly 1.0 since that 

4106 # indicates that an antenna has been completely flagged and skews the median. Then, reset  

4107 # spectrum after found. 

4108 M = np.nanmedian(np.where(R!=1,R,np.nan),2) 

4109 M[:][np.isnan(M[:])]=1.0 

4110 

4111 # Grab the frequencies 

4112 freqs = self.msmeta.chanfreqs(spwin, 'GHz') 

4113 

4114 # Simple scaling to abide by for plots to try somewhat keep default axes 

4115 # but as we do a diag for each spw, scan, fld as the scaling spectrum is  

4116 # found, then we don't store or compare between and get an 'overall'  

4117 # range for plotting  

4118 maxVal=[1.0,1.02,1.05,1.1,1.2,1.3,1.4,1.5,2.0,2.5] 

4119 try: 

4120 plMax = [plM for plM in maxVal if plM >= R.max()][0] 

4121 except IndexError: 

4122 plMax = 3.0 

4123 casalog.post('\n\tWARNING!!!!') 

4124 casalog.post('\tUNREALISTICALLY HIGH RENORM VALUE FOUND!! THERE ARE LIKELY CORRELATOR \ 

4125 ISSUES WITH SCAN '+str(scanin)+' OR THE FITTING HAS DIVERGED.\n') 

4126 plMax = max(plMax, 1.02) 

4127 plMin = min(R.min(), 0.995) 

4128 

4129 # Grab the target name 

4130 target = self.msmeta.namesforfields(fldin)[0] 

4131 

4132 # Initialize the plot 

4133 plt.close('all') 

4134 plt.ioff() 

4135 plt.clf() 

4136 fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10,8)) 

4137 ax_rn = fig.add_subplot(111, frame_on=False) 

4138 ax_rn.set_ylabel('Renorm Amplitude') 

4139 ax_rn.set_xlabel('Frequency (GHz) (TOPO)') 

4140 ax_rn.minorticks_on() 

4141 

4142 # Initialize secondary x-axis and label channels in the correct direction 

4143 ax_rn1 = ax_rn.twiny() 

4144 ax_rn1.set_xlabel('Channel') 

4145 if freqs[0] > freqs[-1]: 

4146 ax_rn1.set_xlim(len(freqs),0) 

4147 else: 

4148 ax_rn1.set_xlim(0,len(freqs)) 

4149 ax_rn1.minorticks_on() 

4150 

4151 # Plot renormalization spectrum for each antenna and correlation using  

4152 # different styles. Also plot median spectrum. 

4153 corColor=['r','b'] 

4154 medColor=['k','g'] 

4155 medLine=[':','--'] 

4156 for iCor in range(R.shape[0]): 

4157 for iAnt in range(R.shape[2]): 

4158 ax_rn.plot(freqs, R[iCor,:,iAnt],c=corColor[iCor],alpha=0.5) 

4159 ax_rn.plot( 

4160 freqs, 

4161 M[iCor], 

4162 c=medColor[iCor], 

4163 linewidth='4', 

4164 linestyle=medLine[iCor] 

4165 ) 

4166 # If provided the original data, plot it in the background. 

4167 if plot_original: 

4168 ax_rn.plot( 

4169 freqs, 

4170 M_atm[iCor], 

4171 c='k', 

4172 linewidth='2', 

4173 linestyle='--', 

4174 alpha=0.25, 

4175 zorder=11 

4176 ) 

4177 

4178 # If supplied, plot a threshold line 

4179 if threshline and threshline < plMax: 

4180 ax_rn.plot( 

4181 [min(freqs), max(freqs)], 

4182 [threshline, threshline], 

4183 linestyle='-', 

4184 c='c', 

4185 linewidth='2' 

4186 ) 

4187 

4188 # Set the labels and such 

4189 ax_rn.set_title( 

4190 self.msname+'\nTarget: '+target+' Spw: '+str(spwin)+' Scan: ' \ 

4191 +str(scanin)+' Field: '+str(fldin), 

4192 {'fontsize': 'medium'} 

4193 ) 

4194 ax_rn.ticklabel_format(useOffset=False) 

4195 ax_rn.set_xlim(min(freqs)*0.99999, max(freqs)*1.00001) 

4196 ax_rn.set_ylim(plMin,plMax) 

4197 

4198 # If True, then show a small yellow area indicating where the spectrum 

4199 # has been blanked. 

4200 if showExcluded: 

4201 # Check to make sure it is not an empty input 

4202 if self.rnstats['inputs']['excludechan']: 

4203 # Check to make sure this spw has anything input, then grab the  

4204 # range and plot it. 

4205 if str(spwin) in self.rnstats['inputs']['excludechan'].keys(): 

4206 ranges = [ 

4207 rng.strip() 

4208 for rng in self.rnstats['inputs']['excludechan'][str(spwin)].split(';') 

4209 ] 

4210 starts, ends = self.interpretExcludechan(ranges, int(spwin)) 

4211 for i in range(len(starts)): 

4212 ax_rn.axvspan( 

4213 freqs[starts[i]], 

4214 freqs[ends[i]], 

4215 ymin=0.05, 

4216 ymax=0.06, 

4217 facecolor='yellow', 

4218 ec='black', 

4219 zorder=0 

4220 ) 

4221 

4222 # If selected, plot the locations where the spectrum was divided during the fitting process 

4223 if plotDivisions: 

4224 dNchan = self.rnstats['inputs'][target][str(spwin)]['dNchan'][-1] 

4225 nseg = self.rnstats['inputs'][target][str(spwin)]['num_segments'][-1] 

4226 if nseg == 1: 

4227 plotDivisions=False 

4228 else: 

4229 xlocs = [iseg*dNchan for iseg in range(1,nseg)] 

4230 ax_rn.vlines( 

4231 freqs[xlocs], 

4232 0.5, 

4233 5, 

4234 linestyles='dotted', 

4235 colors='grey', 

4236 alpha=0.5, 

4237 zorder=10 

4238 ) 

4239 

4240 # If selected, plot the atmospheric transmission profile(s). Note that in Bands 9 and 10, 

4241 # the image sideband atmospheric transmission profile is also plotted. 

4242 if plotATM: 

4243 # If renormalize(correctATM=True) was used, then the ATM profile already exists in 

4244 # a dictionary, use that. Otherwise, grab the profile and image sideband if necessary. 

4245 if len(self.atmtrans.keys())==0: 

4246 if self.Band in [9, 10]: 

4247 ATMprof, ATMprof_imageSB = self.ATMtrans(scanin, spwin, verbose=False) 

4248 else: 

4249 ATMprof=self.ATMtrans(scanin,spwin,verbose=False) 

4250 else: 

4251 if self.Band in [9,10]: 

4252 ATMprof, ATMprof_imageSB = self.atmtrans[target][str(spwin)][str(scanin)] 

4253 else: 

4254 ATMprof=self.atmtrans[target][str(spwin)][str(scanin)] 

4255 

4256 # Setup secondary y-axis using the same frequency axis and plot the profile(s). 

4257 ax_atm = ax_rn.twinx() 

4258 ax_atm.plot(freqs, 100.*ATMprof,c='m',linestyle='-',linewidth=2) 

4259 

4260 if shadeAtm: 

4261 # Find where the ATM lines are by fitting Lorentzian profiles 

4262 atm_centers, atm_gammas = self.fitAtmLines(ATMprof, spwin) 

4263 if self.Band in [9, 10]: 

4264 num_lines = len(atm_centers) 

4265 atm_centers_SB, atm_gammas_SB = self.fitAtmLines(ATMprof_imageSB, spwin) 

4266 atm_centers += atm_centers_SB 

4267 atm_gammas += atm_gammas_SB 

4268 

4269 # For every ATM feature, plot a shaded area so that it is easy to distiguish. 

4270 for i in range(len(atm_centers)): 

4271 # Set the ATM profile we want to report which might vary for Bands 9 and 10 

4272 profile = ATMprof 

4273 if self.Band in [9,10]: 

4274 if i >= num_lines: 

4275 profile = ATMprof_imageSB 

4276 # A Lorentizian has a width of gamma (which is != a Gaussian sigma!)  

4277 # where 2*gamma is the FWHM. Here we go a bit further to capture most 

4278 # of the ATM feature that is above the noise. This is from my empirical 

4279 # estimates from datasets I've collected and seems to capture most of  

4280 # signal without catching real signal for cases where an ATM line is  

4281 # coincident (or nearly so) with a real line.  

4282 # 

4283 # PIPEREQ-228 - Need to protect instances where the 

4284 # fitted feature starts or ends outside the spw! 

4285 atm_start = min( 

4286 max( 

4287 0, 

4288 int(atm_centers[i]-1.3*atm_gammas[i]) 

4289 ), 

4290 len(profile)-1 

4291 ) 

4292 atm_end = max( 

4293 0, 

4294 min( 

4295 int(atm_centers[i]+1.3*atm_gammas[i]), 

4296 len(profile)-1 

4297 ) 

4298 ) 

4299 if atm_start == atm_end: 

4300 continue 

4301 # Draw a shaded region where the line is 

4302 ax_atm.axvspan( 

4303 freqs[atm_start], 

4304 freqs[atm_end], 

4305 ymin=0, 

4306 ymax=10, 

4307 alpha=0.2, 

4308 facecolor='grey' 

4309 ) 

4310 

4311 if self.Band in [9, 10]: 

4312 ax_atm.plot(freqs, 100.*ATMprof_imageSB, c='k', linestyle='-', linewidth=2) 

4313 if self.Band in [9,10]: 

4314 peak = max(np.maximum(ATMprof,ATMprof_imageSB)*100.)+10 

4315 ax_atm.set_ylabel('ATM Transmission (%), Image Sideband') 

4316 else: 

4317 peak = max(ATMprof*100.)+10 

4318 ax_atm.set_ylabel('ATM Transmission (%)') 

4319 ax_atm.yaxis.set_label_position('right') 

4320 

4321 # Avoid labelling values less than 0% since they have no physical meaning. 

4322 # Enforce a range of 100 

4323 atm_ymax = peak 

4324 atm_ymin = peak-100 

4325 ax_atm.set_ylim(atm_ymin, atm_ymax) 

4326 

4327 ## Make sure that we don't label values that are less than 0 since that 

4328 ## has no physical meaning. 

4329 yvals = np.arange(round(atm_ymin), round(atm_ymax)) 

4330 yvals_mod = yvals%20 

4331 ylabels = yvals[list(np.where(yvals_mod==0)[0])] 

4332 ylabels_mask = ylabels >= 0 

4333 ax_atm.set_yticks(ylabels[ylabels_mask]) 

4334 ax_atm.set_yticklabels([str(int(ylbl)) for ylbl in ylabels[ylabels_mask]]) 

4335 

4336 # Save the plotted figure, setting up the plot directory if it doesn't already exist. 

4337 os.makedirs('RN_plots', exist_ok=True) 

4338 fnameM=self.msname+'_ReNormDiagnosticCheck_'+target+'_spw'+str(spwin) \ 

4339 +'_scan'+str(scanin)+'_field'+str(fldin) 

4340 plt.savefig('./RN_plots/'+fnameM+'.png') 

4341 plt.close('all')

4344 def calcSetEdge(self,R,edge=0.01): 

4345 # this changes the edge channels to the median value 

4346 (lpcor,lpcha,lpant)=R.shape 

4347 chlo=int(ceil(edge*lpcha)) 

4348 chhi=lpcha-1-chlo 

4349 for lcor in range(lpcor): 

4350 for lant in range(lpant): 

4351 Rmed = np.median(R[lcor,:,lant]) 

4352 R[lcor,0:chlo,lant]=Rmed 

4353 R[lcor,chhi:,lant]=Rmed 

4354 

4355 def calcMaxConseq(self, linelist): 

4356 cntConsec,maxConsec=0,0 

4357 # loops the differnce of the channels and counts the maximal  

4358 # consecuitve amount - used later as a trigger to replace channels 

4359 # 2021 Feb 16 added that a gap of 2 can be consecutive 

4360 # as sometimes data are just fluctuating above the threshold  

4361 # better to do a full replace vs. piece-meal every other channel 

4362 for diffVal in np.diff(linelist): 

4363 cntConsec = cntConsec + 1 if diffVal == 1 or diffVal == 2 else 0 

4364 maxConsec = max(cntConsec,maxConsec) 

4365 

4366 return maxConsec 

4367 

4368 

4369 def ATMtrans(self, iscan, ispw, ifld=None, verbose=False): 

4370 """ 

4371 Purpose: 

4372 This function will return the atmospheric model for the input spectral window 

4373 and scan. In the case of a Band 9 or 10 spectral window, the atmospheric model 

4374 for the image sideband is also returned.  

4375 

4376 Inputs: 

4377 iscan : int 

4378 The user input scan from which to get the atmospheric model. This is used 

4379 to find the observation time, elevation, and weather information. 

4380 

4381 ispw : int 

4382 The user input spectral window. 

4383 

4384 ifld : int : OPTIONAL 

4385 The user input field ID. This is optional but in the case of mosaics, can 

4386 make the atmospheric model slightly more accurate.  

4387 Default: None 

4388 

4389 verbose : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4390 Setting to True will output additional information as the atmospheric profile  

4391 is calculated. 

4392 Default: False 

4393  

4394 Returns: 

4395 transmission: numpy.array 

4396 (transmission, transmission_SB): numpy.arrays : ONLY FOR BANDS 9 AND 10 

4397 This is a 1-D array with the same length as the number of channels of the input  

4398 scan/spw. The values of the array consist of the atmospheric transmission by  

4399 channel as a fraction between 0.0 and 1.0. 

4400 

4401 """ 

4402 if verbose: 

4403 casalog.post(' Getting ATM transmission profile for spw='+str(ispw)+' and scan='+str(iscan)) 

4404 

4405 # Input iscan should be type(int) but if not, attempt to use the first index. 

4406 if type(iscan) is list: 

4407 iscan=iscan[0] 

4408 

4409 # Find the field if none supplied 

4410 if ifld is None: 

4411 # Find all fields associated with this scan 

4412 ifld = self.msmeta.fieldsforscan(iscan) 

4413 # If there is more than 1 field, it is a mosaic. Take the central field value, hoping 

4414 # that it is near the center... 

4415 if len(ifld) > 1: 

4416 if verbose: 

4417 casalog.post('\tInput scan is a mosaic but no field was supplied. Will attempt to use '+ \ 

4418 'central field number.\n') 

4419 ifld = int(floor(np.median(ifld))) 

4420 else: 

4421 ifld = int(ifld[0]) 

4422 

4423 # Fixed parameters adopted from Todd's aU and plotbandpass3 code 

4424 # - could make options later but probably not required for what we need this function to do 

4425 dP=5.0 

4426 dPm=1.1 

4427 maxAltitude=60.0 

4428 h0=1.0 

4429 atmType = 1 

4430 nbands = 1 

4431 telescopeName = 'ALMA' 

4432 

4433 # Get x-axis information 

4434 # 

4435 # Hanning implementation:  

4436 # We want to get the full resolution ATM model and then hanning smooth it ourselves 

4437 # so we need to specify the correct number of channels. However, we need to be careful 

4438 # about paying attention to the cycle. Pre-cycle 3 data does not have any way of reliably 

4439 # getting the binning factor. So for those datasets we will want to just use the same 

4440 # number of channels and deal with it. For everything else, we will get the binning  

4441 # factor from the MS and apply that binning later.  

4442 #binningFactor = self.onlineBinningFactor()[ispw] 

4443 #numchan = self.msmeta.nchan(ispw)*binningFactor 

4444 #freqs = np.linspace( 

4445 # self.msmeta.chanfreqs(ispw,'GHz')[0], 

4446 # self.msmeta.chanfreqs(ispw,'GHz')[-1], 

4447 # numchan 

4448 # ) 

4449 # 

4450 # No benefit was found from implementing Hanning smoothing of the profile, so just 

4451 # using the profile as is. 

4452 freqs = self.msmeta.chanfreqs(ispw, 'GHz') 

4453 numchan = self.msmeta.nchan(ispw) 

4454 reffreq=0.5*(freqs[int(numchan/2)-1]+freqs[int(numchan/2)]) 

4455 

4456 # Get some metadata information about the scan. We need the sky location in Azimuth  

4457 # and Elevation to know the airmass contribution. Here we use the median scan time to 

4458 # calculate the Elevation, assuming that scan times aren't ridiculously long, that should 

4459 # be good enough for the entire scan. The times will also help us read the weather 

4460 # tables to get the right PWV values out.  

4461 mydirection=self.renormradec2rad(self.renormdirection2radec(self.msmeta.phasecenter(ifld))) 

4462 scanTimes = self.msmeta.timesforscan(iscan) 

4463 myscantime = np.median(scanTimes) 

4464 scanLength = scanTimes[-1] - scanTimes[0] 

4465 casalog.filterMsg('Position:') # message filter as this prints ALMA's position each call 

4466 azel=self.renormcomputeAzElFromRADecMJD(mydirection,myscantime/86400.) 

4467 casalog.clearFilterMsgList() 

4468 airmass = 1.0/np.cos((90.-azel[1])*np.pi/180.) 

4469 

4470 # Get weather results from the MS tables and populate variables from results. 

4471 weatherResult = self.renormWeather(iscan, verbose=False) 

4472 P= weatherResult[0]['pressure'] 

4473 H= weatherResult[0]['humidity'] 

4474 T= weatherResult[0]['temperature']+273.15 

4475 # Sometimes weather values passed are zeros, even if going through the full weather code. 

4476 # In those cases, set to the default values.  

4477 if P == 0: 

4478 P = 563.0 

4479 if H == 0: 

4480 H = 20.0 

4481 if T == 0: 

4482 T = 273.15 

4483 

4484 # Get the median PWV.  

4485 # The PWV measurements are taken before or after scans, so we create a timerange over 

4486 # which to look for those measurements and take the median of those found values.  

4487 # If none are found, then we fall back to using the PWV for the Band from the  

4488 # sensitivity calculator. 

4489 timerange = [scanTimes[0] - scanLength / 2., scanTimes[0] + scanLength/2.] 

4490 pwvmedian=self.renormMedianPWV(timerange, verbose=False) 

4491 if pwvmedian == 0: 

4492 self.corrATM=False 

4493 # get the band and then set these from quartiles 

4494 pwvmedian = self.usePWV[self.Band] # so at least it will make resonable plots 

4495 

4496 # Need the inputs to be in a specific form (dictionary) which the quanta tool does for us. 

4497 myqa = qatool() 

4498 

4499 # Gather frequency information into the form we'll need to make the model. 

4500 # For Bands 9 and 10, the spectral window also has atmospheric contributions from the  

4501 # image sideband which we must also calculate.  

4502 if self.Band in [9,10]: 

4503 nbands = 2 

4504 freqs_SB, chansep_SB, center_SB, width_SB = self.getImageSBFreqs(ispw) 

4505 fCenter = myqa.quantity([reffreq, center_SB],'GHz') 

4506 chansep=(freqs[-1]-freqs[0])/(numchan-1) 

4507 fResolution = myqa.quantity([chansep, -chansep],'GHz') 

4508 fWidth = myqa.quantity([numchan*chansep, numchan*-chansep],'GHz') 

4509 else: 

4510 fCenter = myqa.quantity(reffreq,'GHz') 

4511 chansep=(freqs[-1]-freqs[0])/(numchan-1) 

4512 fResolution = myqa.quantity(chansep,'GHz') 

4513 fWidth = myqa.quantity(numchan*chansep,'GHz') 

4514 

4515 # Setup the CASA atmosphere tool and generate the model.  

4516 # Note this is more or less from inside Todd's aU of CalcAtmTransmission 

4517 # from Plotbandpass3.py code 

4518 myat=attool() 

4519 ATMresult = myat.initAtmProfile(humidity=H, temperature=myqa.quantity(T,"K"), 

4520 altitude=myqa.quantity(5059,"m"), 

4521 pressure=myqa.quantity(P,'mbar'), 

4522 atmType=atmType, 

4523 h0=myqa.quantity(h0,"km"), 

4524 maxAltitude=myqa.quantity(maxAltitude,"km"), 

4525 dP=myqa.quantity(dP,"mbar"), 

4526 dPm=dPm) 

4527 # CASA 5 vs 6 check 

4528 if type(ATMresult) == tuple: 

4529 ATMresult = ATMresult[0] 

4530 

4531 # This sets the frequency information and the PWV measurement 

4532 myat.initSpectralWindow(nbands,fCenter,fWidth,fResolution) 

4533 myat.setUserWH2O(myqa.quantity(pwvmedian,'mm')) 

4534 

4535 # Now calculate the model based on inputs provided above and get the transmission out 

4536 dry = np.array(myat.getDryOpacitySpec(0)[1]) # CO, O3, etc.  

4537 wet = np.array(myat.getWetOpacitySpec(0)[1]['value']) # water absorption 

4538 transmission = np.exp(-airmass*(wet+dry)) # e^-tau;  

4539 if self.Band in [9,10]: 

4540 dry_SB = np.array(myat.getDryOpacitySpec(1)[1]) 

4541 wet_SB = np.array(myat.getWetOpacitySpec(1)[1]['value']) 

4542 transmission_SB = np.exp(-airmass*(wet_SB+dry_SB)) 

4543 

4544 # Close the tools 

4545 myat.close() 

4546 myqa.done() 

4547 

4548 # caution, there is a netsideband affect - LSB and USB 

4549 # if netsideband %2 == 0 then sense = 2, else 1 

4550 # if 1, the trasnsmission flips over the loop in channels  

4551 

4552 mytb.open(self.msname+'/SPECTRAL_WINDOW') 

4553 refFreq = mytb.getcol('REF_FREQUENCY') 

4554 net_sideband = mytb.getcol('NET_SIDEBAND') 

4555 measFreqRef = mytb.getcol('MEAS_FREQ_REF') 

4556 spwname=mytb.getcol('NAME') 

4557 mytb.close() 

4558 

4559 sense=0 

4560 # LSB are =1, USB are +2 - lower need reversing 

4561 if refFreq[ispw]*1e-9>np.mean(freqs): 

4562 if net_sideband[ispw] % 2 == 0: 

4563 sense = 1 

4564 else: 

4565 sense = 2 

4566 

4567 if sense == 1: 

4568 if verbose: 

4569 casalog.post('********* REVERSING THE ATM FOUND FOR LSB ***********') 

4570 transmission = transmission[::-1] # reverse the order 

4571 if self.Band in [9, 10]: 

4572 transmission_SB = transmission_SB[::-1] 

4573 

4574 # Hanning implementation: 

4575 # Smooth the calculated transmission profile by a Hanning kernel 

4576 # and then "decimate" the smoothed signal back down to the correct 

4577 # number of channels. The Hanning smoothing sometimes drops the  

4578 # edge channels which doesn't actually affect the data (even if it's 

4579 # applied) but looks bad. So we set the edge channels equal to the  

4580 # one next to it so it looks better. 

4581 #transmission = np.convolve(transmission, [0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.25, 0], mode='same') 

4582 #transmission = transmission[::binningFactor] 

4583 #transmission[0] = transmission[1] 

4584 #transmission[-1] = transmission[-2] 

4585 #if self.Band in [9, 10]: 

4586 # transmission_SB = np.convolve(transmission_SB, [0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.25, 0], mode='same') 

4587 # transmission_SB = transmission_SB[::binningFactor] 

4588 # transmission_SB[0] = transmission_SB[1] 

4589 # transmission_SB[-1] = transmission_SB[-2] 

4590 

4591 if self.Band in [9, 10]: 

4592 return np.array(transmission), np.array(transmission_SB) 

4593 else: 

4594 return transmission 

4595 

4596 def onlineBinningFactor(self): 

4597 """ 

4598 Purpose: 

4599 Return the online channel binning factor for the relevant spectral 

4600 windows. Note that for early data (<Cycle 3) this will return the  

4601 wrong values (i.e. it always returns 1). 

4602 

4603 This is only used in the Hanning smoothing application of ATM  

4604 corrections which is currently not implemented. 

4605 """ 

4606 mytb.open(self.msname+'/SPECTRAL_WINDOW') 

4607 bins = mytb.getcol('SDM_NUM_BIN') 

4608 mytb.close() 

4609 return bins 

4610 

4611 

4612 # LM added  

4613 def ATMcorrection(self,R,inscan, inspw, infld, calscan, calname, verbose=False): 

4614 # this is the code that will do the real difference between the  

4615 # bandpass and the input target and make a correction to the  

4616 # R, i.e the target AC / Bp AC 

4617 

4618 # R is the AC input 

4619 if verbose: 

4620 casalog.post(' ***** Doing an ATM transmission correction for the ATM line in spw'+str(inspw)+' scan'+str(inscan)+' field'+str(infld)+'*****') 

4621 

4622 # crude theory here - just correct back in by the BP (or phase) and Target model transmission curves  

4623 # R is Tar / bandpass (or phase) 

4624 # so we multiply back in the ATM ?  

4625 fldnam=self.msmeta.namesforfields(infld)[0] 

4626 

4627 # imporved way - get ratio spectrum to find actually differences and then median outside ant loop 

4628 # 

4629 # AL - Is this the right order??? Souldn't it be Bandpass/Target?? Also, does it make sense to subtract the medians  

4630 # first rather than multiplying the ratio and then subtract the median? 

4631 # - The order is indeed correct. The ACs are basically Tsys measurements which are a  

4632 # measure of the sky brightness which has an atmospheric contribution equal to e^tau. 

4633 # Therefore, to mitigate this effect, we must multiply by e^-tau which we estimate 

4634 # via the atmospheric model.  

4635 # - I do think that using the median causes ill effects and is the wrong thing to do. 

4636 # It ends up changing the line peaks even away from the atm features. Therefore, I  

4637 # removed it.  

4638 # - There are additional effects that are still present because 1) the models aren't perfect 

4639 # but 2) there are additional terms for when a line is located in an atm line because that 

4640 # line is being attenuated by e^-tau. Currently, all we are doing is the simple first step. 

4641 #ratioATM = self.atmtrans[fldnam][str(inspw)][str(inscan)] / self.atmtrans[calfld][str(inspw)][calscan] 

4642 if self.Band in [9,10]: 

4643 sidebands=2 

4644 else: 

4645 sidebands=1 

4646 for i in range(sidebands): 

4647 if sidebands == 2: 

4648 trg_atm = self.atmtrans[fldnam][str(inspw)][str(inscan)][i] 

4649 cal_atm = self.atmtrans[calname][str(inspw)][str(calscan)][i] 

4650 else: 

4651 trg_atm = self.atmtrans[fldnam][str(inspw)][str(inscan)] 

4652 cal_atm = self.atmtrans[calname][str(inspw)][str(calscan)] 

4653 ratioATM = trg_atm/cal_atm 

4654 #ratioMed = np.array(np.median(ratioATM)) 

4655 # shift to baseline of average 1.0 

4656 #ratioATM = ratioATM + (1.0 - ratioMed) 

4657 

4658 for jcor in range(R.shape[0]): 

4659 for lpant in range(R.shape[2]): 

4660 # TESTING casalog.post('ATM correcting corr '+str(jcor)+' antenna '+str(lpant)) 

4661 

4662 # simple correction, the target is attenuated by its own ATM, so we multiply back 

4663 # whereas "R" here is Tar_AC/BP_AC and so to correct the BP attenuated by its own 

4664 # ATM profile we have to divide by BP ATM 

4665 # essntially we are multiplying R by (Tar_ATM/BP_ATM) - NB first test was doing just that and result were actually good 

4666 ## OLD FIRST WAY R[jcor,:,lpant] = R[jcor,:,lpant] * (self.atmtrans[fldnam][str(inspw)][str(inscan)] / self.atmtrans[calfld][str(inspw)][calscan]) 

4667 R[jcor,:,lpant] = R[jcor,:,lpant] * ratioATM 

4668 

4669 # - improved method - set already R to ~1.0 median and the ATM ratio spectrum (done above), then correct (more notes below) 

4670 #medR = np.array(np.median(R[jcor,:,lpant])) 

4671 #R[jcor,:,lpant] = (R[jcor,:,lpant]+(1.0-medR)) * ratioATM  

4672 

4673 # LM notes: 

4674 

4675 # first crude tests: 

4676 # applying the correction directly as the ratio only between Tar_ATM/BP_ARM as 

4677 # a multiplication accross the entire SPW will act to change the scaling 

4678 # from real astronomical lines. e.g., 

4679 # - imagine an scaling spectrum (Tar_AutoCorr/BP_AutoCorr) with a baseline at ~0.9, an astronomical line that peaks at 1.2  

4680 # in the middle of the SPW, and away from the ATM line that causes a dip down to 0.8 at the upper edge 

4681 # if one were to fit this to obtain the scaling spectrum, the peak rescaling is 1.3, i.e. 1.0-0.9 = 0.1 + 1.2 peak. 

4682 # - consider the ratio of ATM transmission (Tar_ATM/BP_ATM) is ~0.95 AWAY from the ATM line and 1.15 at the ATM feature 

4683 # this means the baseline of the scaling spectrum * ratio ATM transmission becomes 0.9 * 0.95 -> 0.855 

4684 # while the peak astronomical line will become 1.2 * 0.95 -> 1.14 

4685 # the ATM line would be almost entirely corrected out, i.e 0.8 * 1.1 -> 0.88 - close to the new baseline 

4686 # however now fitting this spectrum, the baseline to peak astronomical line is 1.0-0.855 + 1.14 = 1.285 

4687 # thus the overall peak resacling as reduced by 1.3 - 1.285 = 0.015, 1.5% 

4688 # -- the point is the ATM ratio, and the Tar_AC/BP_AC spectra are not baselined, the have  

4689 # an aribtary baseline y scale. 

4690 

4691 ## anyway, better to get average and apply 

4692 # (i) shift all "R" scaling spectra to a baseline of ~1 (i.e. like first part of fitting code does anyway) 

4693 # (ii) shift the ATM trans ratio correction to a baseline of 1 

4694 # (iii) apply the multiplication, only regions close to the ATM line, i.e. not = 1 will 

4695 # but changed - i.e. more-or-less correcting out the ATM line residual between target and BP 

4696 # there is some low level 'shape' remainig in the ATM line channels - but  

4697 # this correction is made before the fitting, which goes 'bad/divergent' when ATM lines exist as 

4698 # lorenzian like profiles and cannot be fitted out - this code doesn't need to fully correct  

4699 # the ATM profile, it should just remove most of the ATM residual differences so the rest of the  

4700 # renorm code can handle fitting the scaling spectrum 

4701 

4702 # option, maybe set the ATM ratio spectrum to 1.0 i.e. no scaling to any channels 

4703 # except where the ATM transmission is deeper than a given value ? 

4704 

4705 # TESTING TO CODE - i.e. run with and without ATM on many data and see effect on % scaling 

4706 

4707 # No return acts on the rescaling spectrum directly  

4708 

4709 def suggestAtmExclude(self, target, spw, return_command=False, return_dict=False): 

4710 """ 

4711 Purpose: 

4712 Given that renormalization() has been run with the checkFalsePositives=True 

4713 flag, the self.atmMask attribute has been filled with information where 

4714 there are atmospheric features in the spectrum. This function will merge 

4715 the masks from all scans and suggest channel ranges that one may input back 

4716 into renormalization() using the excludechan parameter.  

4717 

4718 Inputs: 

4719 target : string 

4720 The target source evaluated in renormalization() 

4721 

4722 spw : string 

4723 The spectral window you wish to evaluate a mask for assuming that it 

4724 was also run in the renormalization() call.  

4725 

4726 return_command : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4727 If set to True, then a string is returned with the correct syntax to 

4728 put into the excludechan option of a self.renormalization() call. 

4729 Default: False 

4730 

4731 return_dict : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4732 If set to True, then a dictionary is returned with the correct syntax 

4733 to fill the excludechan parameter of the self.renormalize() method. 

4734 Default: False 

4735 NOTE: This takes priority over return_command if both are set to True. 

4736 

4737 Outputs: 

4738 A list of list pairs suggesting ranges for input into the excludechan  

4739 option of renormalization(). 

4740 """ 

4741 

4742 

4743 def subsets(chans): 

4744 """ 

4745 Purpose: Find subset ranges within an array of consecutive values and 

4746 return the sub-ranges. 

4747 """ 

4748 class groupby: 

4749 # A subset task of the itertools package. 

4750 # https://docs.python.org/3/library/itertools.html#itertools.groupby 

4751 

4752 # [k for k, g in groupby('AAAABBBCCDAABBB')] --> A B C D A B 

4753 # [list(g) for k, g in groupby('AAAABBBCCD')] --> AAAA BBB CC D 

4754 def __init__(self, iterable, key=None): 

4755 if key is None: 

4756 key = lambda x: x 

4757 self.keyfunc = key 

4758 self.it = iter(iterable) 

4759 self.tgtkey = self.currkey = self.currvalue = object() 

4760 

4761 def __iter__(self): 

4762 return self 

4763 

4764 def __next__(self): 

4765 self.id = object() 

4766 while self.currkey == self.tgtkey: 

4767 self.currvalue = next(self.it) # Exit on StopIteration 

4768 self.currkey = self.keyfunc(self.currvalue) 

4769 self.tgtkey = self.currkey 

4770 return (self.currkey, self._grouper(self.tgtkey, self.id)) 

4771 

4772 def _grouper(self, tgtkey, id): 

4773 while self.id is id and self.currkey == tgtkey: 

4774 yield self.currvalue 

4775 try: 

4776 self.currvalue = next(self.it) 

4777 except StopIteration: 

4778 return 

4779 self.currkey = self.keyfunc(self.currvalue) 

4780 

4781 def itemgetter(*items): 

4782 # A subset task of the operator package. 

4783 # https://docs.python.org/3/library/operator.html#operator.itemgetter 

4784 if len(items) == 1: 

4785 item = items[0] 

4786 def g(obj): 

4787 return obj[item] 

4788 else: 

4789 def g(obj): 

4790 return tuple(obj[item] for item in items) 

4791 return g 

4792 

4793 def consecutive_groups(iterable, ordering=lambda x: x): 

4794 """ 

4795 A subset of the more-itertools package. 

4796 https://more-itertools.readthedocs.io/en/stable 

4797 /_modules/more_itertools/more.html#consecutive_groups 

4798 

4799 Yield groups of consecutive items using :func:`itertools.groupby`. 

4800 The *ordering* function determines whether two items are adjacent by 

4801 returning their position. 

4802 

4803 By default, the ordering function is the identity function. This is 

4804 suitable for finding runs of numbers: 

4805 

4806 >>> iterable = [1, 10, 11, 12, 20, 30, 31, 32, 33, 40] 

4807 >>> for group in consecutive_groups(iterable): 

4808 ... print(list(group)) 

4809 [1] 

4810 [10, 11, 12] 

4811 [20] 

4812 [30, 31, 32, 33] 

4813 [40] 

4814 

4815 For finding runs of adjacent letters, try using the :meth:`index` method 

4816 of a string of letters: 

4817 

4818 >>> from string import ascii_lowercase 

4819 >>> iterable = 'abcdfgilmnop' 

4820 >>> ordering = ascii_lowercase.index 

4821 >>> for group in consecutive_groups(iterable, ordering): 

4822 ... print(list(group)) 

4823 ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'] 

4824 ['f', 'g'] 

4825 ['i'] 

4826 ['l', 'm', 'n', 'o', 'p'] 

4827 

4828 Each group of consecutive items is an iterator that shares it source with 

4829 *iterable*. When an an output group is advanced, the previous group is 

4830 no longer available unless its elements are copied (e.g., into a ``list``). 

4831 

4832 >>> iterable = [1, 2, 11, 12, 21, 22] 

4833 >>> saved_groups = [] 

4834 >>> for group in consecutive_groups(iterable): 

4835 ... saved_groups.append(list(group)) # Copy group elements 

4836 >>> saved_groups 

4837 [[1, 2], [11, 12], [21, 22]] 

4838 

4839 Borrowed for PL use from https://pypi.org/project/more-itertools/ 

4840 """ 

4841 for k, g in groupby( 

4842 enumerate(iterable), key=lambda x: x[0] - ordering(x[1]) 

4843 ): 

4844 yield map(itemgetter(1), g) 

4845 

4846 subsets = [list(group) for group in consecutive_groups(chans)] 

4847 ranges = [] 

4848 for ss in subsets: 

4849 ranges.append([min(ss), max(ss)]) 

4850 return ranges 

4851 

4852 # Get list of scans that were evaluated 

4853 scans = list(self.atmMask[target][spw].keys()) 

4854 

4855 # We need to compile a "complete" atmospheric mask. Since the objects may set throughout 

4856 # the course of an observation, the atmospheric profile can get worse, leading to a  

4857 # slightly different profile with wider wings. This compiles all the atmospheric masks 

4858 # together into a single, full mask.  

4859 # 

4860 # Note that the self.atmMask arrays are set to True where atmospheric features were found 

4861 # and False otherwise. 

4862 full_mask = self.atmMask[target][spw][scans[0]] 

4863 if len(scans) > 1: 

4864 for scan in scans[1:]: 

4865 full_mask = np.logical_or(full_mask, self.atmMask[target][spw][scan]) 

4866 

4867 # With the full mask, get the channel numbers where there are atmospheric features and  

4868 # calculate the channel ranges of the features. 

4869 atm_channels = np.where(full_mask == True)[0] 

4870 ranges = subsets(atm_channels) 

4871 

4872 # Return either the ranges themselves or a flagging command compiling the ranges. 

4873 if return_dict: 

4874 if len(ranges) == 0: 

4875 return {str(spw):''} 

4876 elif len(ranges) > 1: 

4877 full_range = '' 

4878 for rng in ranges: 

4879 full_range+=str(rng[0])+'~'+str(rng[1])+';' 

4880 return {str(spw): full_range[:-1]} 

4881 else: 

4882 return {str(spw): str(ranges[0][0])+'~'+str(ranges[0][1])} 

4883 elif return_command: 

4884 if len(ranges) == 0: 

4885 return 'No flagging suggested.' 

4886 elif len(ranges) > 1: 

4887 cmd = 'excludechan={"'+str(spw)+'":"' 

4888 for rng in ranges: 

4889 cmd += str(rng[0])+'~'+str(rng[1])+';' 

4890 cmd = cmd[:-1] + '"}' 

4891 else: 

4892 cmd = 'excludechan={"'+str(spw)+'":"'+str(ranges[0][0])+'~'+str(ranges[0][1])+'"}' 

4893 return cmd 

4894 else: 

4895 return ranges 

4896

4898 def getband(self,freq): 

4899 """  

4900 Identify the Band for specific frequency (in GHz) 

4901 

4902 Note that the Band 2/3 identification is currently not 

4903 guaranteed to be correct. 

4904 """ 

4905 lo=np.array([35,67,84,125,157,211,275,385,602,787])*1e9 

4906 hi=np.array([50,83.999999999,116,163,212,275,373,500,720,950])*1e9 

4907 

4908 return np.arange(1,len(lo)+1)[(freq>lo)&(freq<hi)][0]

4910 def writeTsysTemps(self, dictIn=None, rettemplist=False): 

4911 """ 

4912 Purpose: 

4913 Uses the dictionary from the Tsys Plotting code and will return a 

4914 list with each element being a line to be entered into the  

4915 tsystemplate in PL style 

4916 

4917 Optionally, an input dictionary in correct syntax can be passed.  

4918  

4919 Using retflchan=True in the plotRelTsysSpectra() method will save 

4920 the dictionary to the argument of the call if you want a manual  

4921 view of the dict or to see and edit and input manually into this  

4922 flag_lines code. 

4923 

4924 NOTE: This is to be used with caution as it has not been validated 

4925 yet and is mainly for helping with manual DR only!!! 

4926  

4927 Inputs: 

4928 dictIn : dictionary : OPTIONAL 

4929 If desired, a user may input a dictionary of flags. If one is 

4930 not input, then the output of self.plotRelTsysSpectra() is used 

4931 instead. 

4932 Default: None 

4933 

4934 rettemplist : boolean : OPTIONAL 

4935 If set to True, then the flags constructed during this script,  

4936 in addition to being written to a file via self.writeTsysFlags(), 

4937 will be returned as a list of strings. 

4938 

4939 Outputs: 

4940 A file of Tsys flags is written via the self.writeTsysFlags() method. 

4941 Additionally, if rettemplist=True, a list of strings is returned that 

4942 contains all the flagging commands. 

4943  

4944 Suggestions for Improvement: 

4945 - Syntax is not currently explicity checked for the dictIn option.  

4946 """ 

4947 if dictIn: 

4948 if type(dictIn) is not dict: 

4949 casalog.post('Option dictIn must be a dictionary!') 

4950 raise TypeError( 

4951 'Option dictIn of writeTsysTemps() must be a dictionary.' 

4952 ) 

4953 else: 

4954 dictIn = self.TsysReturn 

4955 

4956 listToKeep=[] 

4957 TDM=True 

4958 for keyuse in dictIn.keys(): 

4959 spwKeep = keyuse.split('=')[-1] 

4960 # then sub layer is the scan key - not intent based its  

4961 # code based on Tsys TARGET intent scans  

4962 scanKeys = dictIn[keyuse].keys() 

4963 # check if the Tsys are in same SPW setup, i.e. in the fdmspws, then ACA  

4964 # and uses a slightly different option in channel_ranges funct. 

4965 if int(spwKeep) in self.fdmspws: 

4966 TDM=False 

4967 for scankeyuse in scanKeys: 

4968 scanKeep= scankeyuse.split('=')[-1] 

4969 # pass to channel_ranges which will do some consolidation and buffering (i.e. few extra channels) 

4970 chanRans = self.channel_ranges(dictIn[keyuse][scankeyuse], TDM=TDM) 

4971 for chanranlp in chanRans: 

4972 spwStrUse = str(spwKeep)+':'+str(chanranlp[0])+'~'+str(chanranlp[1]) 

4973 

4974 listToKeep.append("mode=\'manual\' spw=\'{}\' scan=\'{}\' reason=\'QA2:tsysflag_tsys_channel\'".format(spwStrUse,scanKeep)) 

4975 

4976 # already write the file here for the logs 

4977 self.writeTsysFlags(listToKeep) 

4978 

4979 # passes out template list to argument as option 

4980 if rettemplist: 

4981 return listToKeep

4983 def channel_ranges(self, channels, TDM=True): 

4984 """ 

4985 Purpose: 

4986 Given a list of channels, this will return a list of ranges that  

4987 describe them accounting for a buffer and gap in input that can be assumed  

4988 as consecutive. 

4989 """ 

4990 channels.sort() 

4991 

4992 if TDM: 

4993 addChan = 1 

4994 gapChan = 3 

4995 else: 

4996 # To combat piece wise flags due to channels triggering just around 

4997 # the threshold, set extra buffers. 

4998 addChan = 5 

4999 gapChan = 10 

5000 

5001 channel_range = [channels[0]-addChan, channels[0]] # gives a wider flag buffer  

5002 

5003 for i, chan in enumerate(channels): 

5004 # checks if a gap of 3 and assumes continous 

5005 if chan <= channel_range[1] + gapChan: 

5006 # gives a wider buffer to written flag 

5007 channel_range[1] = chan+addChan 

5008 else: 

5009 # for discountinuty will call this funct again and 'appends'  

5010 return [channel_range] + self.channel_ranges(channels[i:]) 

5011 

5012 # get here if last channel reached 

5013 return [channel_range]

5017 Purpose: 

5018 Given the list from the writeTsysTemps method that makes a list of  

5019 flag template compatible strings, this code simply writes a PL  

5020 style flag template file at the most detailed level, i.e. spw and  

5021 channel per scan triggered. 

5022 """ 

5023 with open(self.msname+'_ReNormflagtsystemplate.txt', 'w') as file_tsys: 

5024 # loop over list and write 

5025 for tsys_flag in tsys_flags: 

5026 file_tsys.write(tsys_flag+'\n')

5028 def renormcomputeAzElFromRADecMJD(self, raDec, mjd): 

5029 """ 

5030 Purpose: 

5031 Computes the azimuth and elevation for a specified RA, Dec, and MJD  

5032 for ALMA observations using the CASA measures tool. 

5033 

5034 Adapted from Todd Hunter's AU tool computeAzElFromRADecMJD.  

5035  

5036 Inputs: 

5037 raDec : list or tuple 

5038 Must be in radians: [ra,dec] 

5039 

5040 mjd : float 

5041 Must be in days. 

5042 

5043 Output: 

5044 The azimuth and elevation are returned as a list in degrees. 

5045 """ 

5046 # Open CASA tools and define relevant quantities 

5047 myme = metool() 

5048 myqa = qatool() 

5049 frame='AZEL' 

5050 raQuantity = myqa.quantity(raDec[0], 'rad') 

5051 decQuantity = myqa.quantity(raDec[1], 'rad') 

5052 mydir = myme.direction('J2000', raQuantity, decQuantity) 

5053 myme.doframe(myme.epoch('mjd', myqa.quantity(mjd, 'd'))) 

5054 observatory='ALMA' 

5055 myme.doframe(myme.observatory(observatory)) 

5056 myqa.done() 

5057 myazel = myme.measure(mydir,frame) 

5058 myme.done() 

5059 

5060 # Once the inputs and frames are specified, pull out solution.  

5061 myaz = myazel['m0']['value'] 

5062 myel = myazel['m1']['value'] 

5063 

5064 # Want output in Degrees  

5065 myaz *= 180/np.pi 

5066 myel *= 180/np.pi 

5067 

5068 return([myaz,myel])

5072 def renormradec2rad(self, radecstring): 

5073 """ 

5074 Purpose: 

5075 Convert a sky position from a single RA/Dec sexagesimal string  

5076 to RA and Dec in radians. 

5077 

5078 Adapted from Todd Hunter's AU tool radec2rad. 

5079 

5080 Inputs: 

5081 radecstring: string 

5082 Any leading 'J2000' string is removed before consideration.  

5083  

5084 The RA and Dec portions can be separated by a comma or a space. 

5085  

5086 The RA portion of the string must be colon-delimited, space- 

5087 delimited, or 'h/m/s' delimited.  

5088  

5089 The Dec portion of the string can be either ":", "." or space- 

5090 delimited. If it is "." delimited, then it must have degrees,  

5091 minutes, *and* seconds. 

5092 

5093 Returns: 

5094 The RA and Dec are retuned as a tuple in radians. 

5095 """ 

5096 # Strip off J2000 leading string if it exists. 

5097 if radecstring.find('J2000')==0: 

5098 radecstring = radecstring.replace('J2000','') 

5099 

5100 # If in hms form, replace to ":" separated form. 

5101 if (radecstring.find('h')>0 and radecstring.find('d')>0): 

5102 radecstring = radecstring.replace( 

5103 'h', ':' 

5104 ).replace( 

5105 'm', ':' 

5106 ).replace( 

5107 'd', ':' 

5108 ).replace( 

5109 's','' 

5110 ) 

5111 

5112 # Create a separation between RA and Dec, then split on spaces to find 

5113 # what type of input was used. 

5114 radec1 = radecstring.replace(',',' ') 

5115 tokens = radec1.split() 

5116 

5117 # If input was not space separated, we have RA then Dec. If input was  

5118 # space separated, we have RA and Dec split over 6 items. Otherwise,  

5119 # bad input and reject it.  

5120 if (len(tokens) == 2): 

5121 (ra,dec) = radec1.split() 

5122 elif (len(tokens) == 6): 

5123 h,m,s,d,dm,ds = radec1.split() 

5124 ra = '%s:%s:%s' % (h,m,s) 

5125 dec = '%+f:%s:%s' % (float(d), dm, ds) 

5126 else: 

5127 casalog.post("Invalid format for RA/Dec string: ", radec1) 

5128 raise SyntaxError('Invalid format for RA/Dec string: '+str(radec1)) 

5129 

5130 # Evaluate found RA/Dec input which at this point we know is in ":" format.  

5131 # Strip any errant spaces and split on ":" to get each portion. To get to  

5132 # degrees, we need to follow:  

5133 # ra_degrees = 15 * (ra_hours + ra_minutes/60 + ra_seconds/3600) 

5134 # dec_degress = dec_degrees + dec_minutes/60 + dec_seconds/3600 

5135 tokens = ra.strip().split(':') 

5136 hours = 0 

5137 for i,t in enumerate(tokens): 

5138 hours += float(t)/(60.**i) 

5139 ra1 = hours*15 

5140 # We don't yet know if Dec is in "." or ":" format so account for both. 

5141 if (dec.find(':') > 0): 

5142 tokens = dec.lstrip().split(':') 

5143 elif (dec.find('.') > 0): 

5144 try: 

5145 (d,m,s) = dec.lstrip().split('.') 

5146 except: 

5147 (d,m,s,sfraction) = dec.lstrip().split('.') 

5148 s = s + '.' + sfraction 

5149 tokens = [d,m,s] 

5150 else: # just an integer 

5151 tokens = [dec] 

5152 dec1 = 0 

5153 for i,t in enumerate(tokens): 

5154 dec1 += abs(float(t)/(60.**i)) 

5155 # Account for possibility that Dec can be negative. 

5156 if (dec.lstrip().find('-') == 0): 

5157 dec1 = -dec1 

5158 

5159 # Convert degrees to radians. 

5160 decrad = dec1*np.pi/180. 

5161 rarad = ra1*np.pi/180. 

5162 

5163 return(rarad,decrad) 

5164 

5165 

5166 def renormdirection2radec(self, direction): 

5167 """ 

5168 Purpose: 

5169 Convert a direction dictionary to a sexadecimal string of format: 

5170 HH:MM:SS.SSSSS, +DDD:MM:SS.SSSSSS 

5171 

5172 Adapted from Todd Hunter's AU tool direction2radec. 

5173 

5174 Inputs: 

5175 direction : dictionary 

5176 This input is what is returned from the msmd tool of a pointing, 

5177 i.e. the return of msmdtool().phasecenter. 

5178 

5179 Outputs:  

5180 The RA, Dec pointing direction as a string in sexadecimal format. 

5181 """ 

5182 ra = direction['m0']['value'] 

5183 dec = direction['m1']['value'] 

5184 myqa = qatool() 

5185 prec = 5 

5186 mystring = '%s, %s' % (myqa.formxxx( 

5187 '%.12frad'%ra, 

5188 format='hms', 

5189 prec=prec 

5190 ), 

5191 myqa.formxxx( 

5192 '%.12frad'%dec, 

5193 format='dms', 

5194 prec=prec 

5195 ).replace('.',':',2)) 

5196 myqa.done() 

5197 

5198 return(mystring)

5202 def renormWeather(self, scan, verbose=False): 

5203 '''  

5204 Purpose: 

5205 Returns the weather conditions and time stamps of a given scan.  

5206 This is heavily adapted from Todd Hunter's analysisUtils code, 

5207 au.getWeather() function. 

5208 

5209 Inputs: 

5210 scan : integer 

5211 The scan number. 

5212 

5213 verbose : boolean : OPTIONAL 

5214 If set to true, some additional output is printed to screen. 

5215 

5216 Returns: 

5217 [conditions, myTimes] 

5218 conditions : dictionary 

5219 Includes the average temperature (Celcius), humidity (%),  

5220 and Pressure (mB) for the given scan. 

5221 

5222 myTimes : numpy.array 

5223 List of times during the given scan. 

5224  

5225 ''' 

5226 # Use a standard preferred weather station (as noted in AU task). 

5227 preferredStation = 'TB2' 

5228 conditions = {} 

5229 conditions['pressure']=conditions['temperature']=conditions['humidity'] = 0 

5230 myTimes = self.msmeta.timesforscan(scan) 

5231 

5232 # Get the weather table. 

5233 try: 

5234 # mytb is global tool instance already 

5235 mytb.open(self.msname+'/WEATHER') 

5236 except: 

5237 casalog.post("Could not open the WEATHER table for this ms, default returned.") 

5238 conditions['pressure']=563.0 

5239 conditions['temperature']=0.0 # in deg C 

5240 conditions['humidity'] = 20.0 

5241 return([conditions,myTimes]) 

5242 

5243 # Get all weather information. 

5244 mjdsec = mytb.getcol('TIME') 

5245 indices = np.argsort(mjdsec) # sometimes slightly out of order, fix. 

5246 pressure = mytb.getcol('PRESSURE') 

5247 relativeHumidity = mytb.getcol('REL_HUMIDITY') 

5248 temperature = mytb.getcol('TEMPERATURE') 

5249 # If in units of Kelvin, convert to C 

5250 if (np.mean(temperature) > 100): 

5251 temperature = temperature-273.15 

5252 

5253 # Apply correct ordering 

5254 mjdsec = np.array(mjdsec)[indices] 

5255 pressure = np.array(pressure)[indices] 

5256 relativeHumidity = np.array(relativeHumidity)[indices] 

5257 temperature = np.array(temperature)[indices] 

5258 # Grab weather station IDs. 

5259 if 'NS_WX_STATION_ID' in mytb.colnames(): 

5260 stations = mytb.getcol('NS_WX_STATION_ID') 

5261 else: 

5262 stations = None 

5263 mytb.close() 

5264 

5265 # Get the weather station names. 

5266 wsdict = self.renormWeatherStationNames() 

5267 if wsdict is not None: 

5268 preferredStationID = None 

5269 # Loop over weather stations, searching for the preferred. 

5270 for w in list(wsdict.keys()): 

5271 if wsdict[w].find(preferredStation) >= 0: 

5272 preferredStationID = w 

5273 # If preferred found, use only data from that one, otherwise use all. 

5274 if preferredStationID is None: 

5275 if verbose: 

5276 casalog.post("Preferred station (%s) not found in this dataset. Using all." % (preferredStation)) 

5277 else: 

5278 indices = np.where(stations == preferredStationID) 

5279 mjdsec = np.array(mjdsec)[indices] 

5280 pressure = np.array(pressure)[indices] 

5281 relativeHumidity = np.array(relativeHumidity)[indices] 

5282 temperature = np.array(temperature)[indices] 

5283 stations = np.array(stations)[indices] 

5284 

5285 # Find the overlap of weather measurement times and scan times 

5286 matches = np.where(mjdsec>=min(myTimes))[0] 

5287 matches2 = np.where(mjdsec<=max(myTimes))[0] 

5288 noWeatherData = False 

5289 if (len(matches)>0 and len(matches2) > 0): 

5290 # Average the weather points enclosed by the scan time range. 

5291 selectedValues = range(matches[0], matches2[-1]+1) 

5292 # If there was a either gap in the weather data, or an incredibly short scan duration 

5293 # find the closest in time index. 

5294 if (len(selectedValues) == 0): 

5295 selectedValues = self.renormfindClosestTime(mjdsec, myTimes[0]) 

5296 # If all points are greater than myTime, take the first one. 

5297 elif (len(matches)>0): 

5298 selectedValues = matches[0] 

5299 # If all points are less than myTime, take the last one. 

5300 elif (len(matches2)>0): 

5301 selectedValues = matches2[-1] 

5302 # If here, then the table has no weather data at all (7M?). 

5303 else: 

5304 noWeatherData = True 

5305 

5306 if (noWeatherData): 

5307 conditions['pressure'] = 563.0 

5308 conditions['temperature'] = 0 # Celsius is expected 

5309 conditions['humidity'] = 20.0 

5310 casalog.post("WARNING: No weather data found in the WEATHER table!") 

5311 else: 

5312 # Separate the relevant index values. 

5313 selectPressure = pressure[selectedValues] 

5314 selectTemperature = temperature[selectedValues] 

5315 selectHumidity = relativeHumidity[selectedValues] 

5316 # Check to make sure that there is at least one valid (non-zero) value. 

5317 mask = (selectPressure > 0) 

5318 if not mask.any(): 

5319 casalog.post('No valid weather data for timerange!') 

5320 conditions['pressure'] = 563.0 

5321 conditions['temperature'] = 0 # Celsius is expected 

5322 conditions['humidity'] = 20.0 

5323 # Find average value of each weather condition, using only valid entries. 

5324 else: 

5325 conditions['pressure'] = np.mean(selectPressure[mask]) 

5326 conditions['temperature'] = np.mean(selectTemperature[mask]) 

5327 conditions['humidity'] = np.mean(selectHumidity[mask]) 

5328 if verbose: 

5329 casalog.post(" Pressure = %.2f mb" % (conditions['pressure'])) 

5330 casalog.post(" Temperature = %.2f C" % (conditions['temperature'])) 

5331 casalog.post(" Relative Humidity = %.2f %%" % (conditions['humidity'])) 

5332 

5333 return([conditions,myTimes]) 

5334 

5335 

5336 def renormMedianPWV(self, myTimes=[0,99999999999], verbose=False): 

5337 """ 

5338 Extracts the PWV measurements from the WVR on all antennas all times.  

5339 First, it tries to find the ASDM_CALWVR 

5340 table in the ms. If that fails, it then tries to find the  

5341 ASDM_CALATMOSPHERE table in the ms.  

5342 Returns: 

5343 The median PWV 

5344 For further help and examples, see https://safe.nrao.edu/wiki/bin/view/ALMA/GetMedianPWV 

5345 -- Todd Hunter - aU version 

5346 -- Luke Maud - copied and stripped down for almarenorm to make independent of  

5347 the analysis utilities 

5348 """ 

5349 pwvmean = 0 ## actually is the median  

5350 if (verbose): 

5351 casalog.post("in renormMedianPWV with myTimes = ", myTimes) 

5352 try: 

5353 mytb.open(self.msname+'/ASDM_CALWVR') 

5354 pwvtime = mytb.getcol('startValidTime') # mjdsec 

5355 antenna = mytb.getcol('antennaName') 

5356 pwv = mytb.getcol('water') 

5357 mytb.close() 

5358 # if read but somehow nothing comes back 

5359 if (len(pwv) < 1): 

5360 if verbose: 

5361 casalog.post("Found no data in ASDM_CALWVR table") 

5362 pwv=0 

5363 except: 

5364 pwv = 0 

5365 if type(pwv) is int: 

5366 try: 

5367 pwvtime, antenna, pwv = self.renormPWVFromASDM_CALATMOSPHERE() 

5368 if (len(pwv) < 1): 

5369 if verbose: 

5370 casalog.post("Found no data in ASDM_CALATMOSPHERE table") 

5371 return pwvmean 

5372 except: 

5373 pwv = 0 

5374 

5375 # i.e. didnt get anything from above tables at all 

5376 if type(pwv) is int: 

5377 if verbose: 

5378 casalog.post("Found no data in ASDM_CALWVR nor ASDM_CALATMOSPHERE tables") 

5379 return pwvmean 

5380 

5381 # Data from before May 2016 may have all PWV values set to a default 1.0 rather  

5382 # than a real value. Reject these as there is no real data to use. 

5383 if all(i==1.0 for i in pwv): 

5384 casalog.post('All recorded entries of PWV are set equal to 1.0! No data available.') 

5385 return pwvmean 

5386 

5387 # my times is hardcoded so should find something 

5388 try: 

5389 matches = np.where(np.array(pwvtime)>myTimes[0])[0] 

5390 except: 

5391 if verbose: 

5392 casalog.post("Found no times > %d" % (myTimes[0])) 

5393 return pwvmean 

5394 

5395 # for testing  

5396 #casalog.post("%d matches = " % (len(matches)), matches) 

5397 #casalog.post("%d pwv = " % (len(pwv)), pwv) 

5398 ptime = np.array(pwvtime)[matches] 

5399 matchedpwv = np.array(pwv)[matches] 

5400 matches2 = np.where(ptime<=myTimes[-1])[0] 

5401 # for testing  

5402 #casalog.post("matchedpwv = %s" % (matchedpwv)) 

5403 #casalog.post("pwv = %s" % (pwv)) 

5404 if (len(matches2) < 1): 

5405 # look for the value with the closest start time 

5406 mindiff = 1e12 

5407 for i in range(len(pwvtime)): 

5408 if (abs(myTimes[0]-pwvtime[i]) < mindiff): 

5409 mindiff = abs(myTimes[0]-pwvtime[i]) 

5410 # pwvmean = pwv[i]*1000 

5411 matchedpwv = [] 

5412 for i in range(len(pwvtime)): 

5413 if (abs(abs(myTimes[0]-pwvtime[i]) - mindiff) < 1.0): 

5414 matchedpwv.append(pwv[i]) 

5415 pwvmean = 1000*np.median(matchedpwv) 

5416 if (verbose): 

5417 casalog.post("Taking the median of %d pwv measurements from all antennas = %.3f mm" % (len(matchedpwv),pwvmean)) 

5418 else: 

5419 pwvmean = 1000*np.median(matchedpwv[matches2]) 

5420 if (verbose): 

5421 casalog.post("Taking the median of %d pwv measurements from all antennas = %.3f mm" % (len(matches2),pwvmean)) 

5422 return pwvmean 

5423 # end of getMedianPWV

5426 def renormPWVFromASDM_CALATMOSPHERE(self): 

5427 """ 

5428 Reads the PWV via the water column of the ASDM_CALATMOSPHERE table in MS. 

5429 - Todd Hunter - aU version 

5430 - Luke Maud copied and edited for almarenorm so independent of analysisUtils 

5431 """ 

5432 try: 

5433 mytb.open(self.msname+'/ASDM_CALATMOSPHERE') 

5434 pwvtime = mytb.getcol('startValidTime') # mjdsec 

5435 antenna = mytb.getcol('antennaName') 

5436 pwv = mytb.getcol('water')[0] # There seem to be 2 identical entries per row, so take first one. 

5437 mytb.close() 

5438 except: 

5439 return(0,0,0) 

5440 return(pwvtime, antenna, pwv)
